title: Pneumovax-23 Injection: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Pneumovax-23 injection on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) helps protect against serious infection (such as [meningitis](https://www.webmd.com/children/understanding-meningitis-basics), bacteria in the [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood)) due to certain bacteria ( [Streptococcus](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/understanding-strep-throat-basics) pneumoniae). This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) is important for preventing infection in individuals at risk (such as those [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics), or those living in a nursing home). How to use Pneumovax 23 Vial Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before receiving the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. This vaccine is injected into a muscle or under the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) by a health care professional. When this vaccine is injected into a muscle, it is given in the upper arm or thigh. You may need to have another dose of vaccine if you are still at high risk for infection. This is especially true if you are younger than 65 years old when you receive the first dose of this vaccine. A second dose should not be given until 5 years after your first dose. Ask your health care professional for more details. If you are receiving this vaccination before [spleen](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-spleen) surgery or before receiving [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) [chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/chemotherapy-what-to-expect) or other drugs that decrease your [immune system](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/immune-system-function) function, it should be given at least 2 weeks before these procedures to be effective. Talk to your health care professional for more information. Side Effects Injection site reactions (such as pain, redness, swelling, hard lump), muscle/ [joint](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/joint-pain) aches, or fever may occur. Ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional whether you should take a fever/pain reducer (such as [acetaminophen](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-362/acetaminophen+oral/details)) to help treat these symptoms. [Nausea and vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) may also occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional promptly. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. Tell your health care professional right away if you have any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your health care professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your health care professional right away if you have any serious side effects, including: unusual [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview), tingling/numbness of the hands/feet, [swollen glands](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/swollen-glands). A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice any other effects not listed, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before you receive this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as the preservative phenol, latex or dry natural rubber in the vial stopper), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before using this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: your vaccination/ [immunization](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) history, recent illness/fever, [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment). This vaccine is not recommended for use in children younger than 2 years. During pregnancy, this vaccine should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your health care professional. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: drugs that Overdose Not applicable. It is important to understand the risks and benefits of [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). Discuss this with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional about the need for other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) to prevent possibly severe illness (such as [flu shots](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/fact-sheet-vaccines)). Make sure all of your health care professionals know you have received this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). Make sure a note is placed in your medical record of having received this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). Not applicable. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
